2024 Men's T20 World Cup

diff

2024-08-10T10:44:28Z
Line 1,354: Line 1,354:
South Africa's chase began with the loss of two early wickets, but [[Quinton de Kock]] and [[Tristan Stubbs]] took the total to 106. After they were both dismissed, [[Heinrich Klaasen]] made the fastest fifty in a World Cup final, including scoring 24 runs off the 15th over bowled by Axar Patel. At this point, South Africa required 30 runs in 30 balls with six wickets in hand. However, [[Arshdeep Singh (cricketer)|Arshdeep Singh]], [[Jasprit Bumrah]], and [[Hardik Pandya]] bowled economically in the last 5 overs. Pandya picked up the wicket of Klaasen in the 17th over, Bumrah dismissed [[Marco Jansen]] in the 18th over, and Pandya dismissed [[David Miller (South African cricketer)|David Miller]], the last recognized batsman, off the first ball of the final over. The tail end batsmen were unable to overhaul India's total, and South Africa ended their innings on 169/8, losing by 7 runs.<ref>{{Cite web |last=icc |title=Matches {{!}} ICC Men's T20 World Cup, 2024 |url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/tournaments/t20cricketworldcup/matches/239657/south-africa-vs-india |access-date=2024-07-01 |website=icc |language=en}}</ref>
South Africa's chase began with the loss of two early wickets, but [[Quinton de Kock]] and [[Tristan Stubbs]] took the total to 106. After they were both dismissed, [[Heinrich Klaasen]] made the fastest fifty in a World Cup final, including scoring 24 runs off the 15th over bowled by Axar Patel. At this point, South Africa required 30 runs in 30 balls with six wickets in hand. However, [[Arshdeep Singh (cricketer)|Arshdeep Singh]], [[Jasprit Bumrah]], and [[Hardik Pandya]] bowled economically in the last 5 overs. Pandya picked up the wicket of Klaasen in the 17th over, Bumrah dismissed [[Marco Jansen]] in the 18th over, and Pandya dismissed [[David Miller (South African cricketer)|David Miller]], the last recognized batsman, off the first ball of the final over. The tail end batsmen were unable to overhaul India's total, and South Africa ended their innings on 169/8, losing by 7 runs.<ref>{{Cite web |last=icc |title=Matches {{!}} ICC Men's T20 World Cup, 2024 |url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/tournaments/t20cricketworldcup/matches/239657/south-africa-vs-india |access-date=2024-07-01 |website=icc |language=en}}</ref>


This victory marked India's first ICC title since the [[2013 ICC Champions Trophy]], their first world cup title since the [[2011 Cricket World Cup|2011 ICC Cricket World Cup]], and their second [[T20 World Cup]] crown with the first being the [[2007 ICC World Twenty20|2007]] title. Kohli's knock of 76 runs off 59 balls (including 6 fours and 2 sixes) earned him the [[Player of the Match]] award, while [[Jasprit Bumrah]] received the Player of the Tournament award for his outstanding bowling performance throughout the tournament. Bumrah ended up with 15 wickets towards the end of the tournament.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=29 June 2024 |title=India win T20 World Cup 2024, stun South Africa by 7 runs in final as Bumrah, Hardik nail finish |url=https://indianexpress.com/article/sports/cricket/india-win-t20-world-cup-2024-stun-south-africa-by-7-runs-in-final-9423182/ |website=The Indian Express}}</ref> [[Virat Kohli|Kohli]], [[Rohit Sharma|Sharma]] and [[Ravindra Jadeja|Jadeja]] announced their retirement from the [[Twenty20 International|T20 international]] format after the final.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=30 June 2024 |title=After Virat Kohli, Rohit Sharma announces T20I retirement following World Cup triumph |url=https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/cricket/story/rohit-sharma-t20i-retirement-virat-kohli-world-cup-triumph-barbados-2560206-2024-06-30 |website=India Today}}</ref> The end of the tournament also marked the end of [[Rahul Dravid|Rahul Dravid's]] tenure as the coach of the Indian cricket team as his contract was actually extended after the [[2023 Cricket World Cup]] until this T20 World Cup.
This victory marked India's first ICC title since the [[2013 ICC Champions Trophy]], their first world cup title since the [[2011 Cricket World Cup|2011 ICC Cricket World Cup]], and their second [[T20 World Cup]] crown with the first being the [[2007 ICC World Twenty20|2007]] title. Kohli's knock of 76 runs off 59 balls (including 6 fours and 2 sixes) earned him the [[Player of the Match]] award, while [[Jasprit Bumrah]] received the Player of the Tournament award for his outstanding bowling performance throughout the tournament. Bumrah ended up with 15 wickets with an economy rate of 4.17 towards the end of the tournament.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=29 June 2024 |title=India win T20 World Cup 2024, stun South Africa by 7 runs in final as Bumrah, Hardik nail finish |url=https://indianexpress.com/article/sports/cricket/india-win-t20-world-cup-2024-stun-south-africa-by-7-runs-in-final-9423182/ |website=The Indian Express}}</ref> [[Virat Kohli|Kohli]], [[Rohit Sharma|Sharma]] and [[Ravindra Jadeja|Jadeja]] announced their retirement from the [[Twenty20 International|T20 international]] format after the final.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=30 June 2024 |title=After Virat Kohli, Rohit Sharma announces T20I retirement following World Cup triumph |url=https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/cricket/story/rohit-sharma-t20i-retirement-virat-kohli-world-cup-triumph-barbados-2560206-2024-06-30 |website=India Today}}</ref> The end of the tournament also marked the end of [[Rahul Dravid|Rahul Dravid's]] tenure as the coach of the Indian cricket team as his contract was actually extended after the [[2023 Cricket World Cup]] until this T20 World Cup.


{{Single-innings cricket match
{{Single-innings cricket match

2024 Men's T20 World Cup

diff

2024-08-10T10:43:10Z
Line 1,354: Line 1,354:
South Africa's chase began with the loss of two early wickets, but [[Quinton de Kock]] and [[Tristan Stubbs]] took the total to 106. After they were both dismissed, [[Heinrich Klaasen]] made the fastest fifty in a World Cup final, including scoring 24 runs off the 15th over bowled by Axar Patel. At this point, South Africa required 30 runs in 30 balls with six wickets in hand. However, [[Arshdeep Singh (cricketer)|Arshdeep Singh]], [[Jasprit Bumrah]], and [[Hardik Pandya]] bowled economically in the last 5 overs. Pandya picked up the wicket of Klaasen in the 17th over, Bumrah dismissed [[Marco Jansen]] in the 18th over, and Pandya dismissed [[David Miller (South African cricketer)|David Miller]], the last recognized batsman, off the first ball of the final over. The tail end batsmen were unable to overhaul India's total, and South Africa ended their innings on 169/8, losing by 7 runs.<ref>{{Cite web |last=icc |title=Matches {{!}} ICC Men's T20 World Cup, 2024 |url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/tournaments/t20cricketworldcup/matches/239657/south-africa-vs-india |access-date=2024-07-01 |website=icc |language=en}}</ref>
South Africa's chase began with the loss of two early wickets, but [[Quinton de Kock]] and [[Tristan Stubbs]] took the total to 106. After they were both dismissed, [[Heinrich Klaasen]] made the fastest fifty in a World Cup final, including scoring 24 runs off the 15th over bowled by Axar Patel. At this point, South Africa required 30 runs in 30 balls with six wickets in hand. However, [[Arshdeep Singh (cricketer)|Arshdeep Singh]], [[Jasprit Bumrah]], and [[Hardik Pandya]] bowled economically in the last 5 overs. Pandya picked up the wicket of Klaasen in the 17th over, Bumrah dismissed [[Marco Jansen]] in the 18th over, and Pandya dismissed [[David Miller (South African cricketer)|David Miller]], the last recognized batsman, off the first ball of the final over. The tail end batsmen were unable to overhaul India's total, and South Africa ended their innings on 169/8, losing by 7 runs.<ref>{{Cite web |last=icc |title=Matches {{!}} ICC Men's T20 World Cup, 2024 |url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/tournaments/t20cricketworldcup/matches/239657/south-africa-vs-india |access-date=2024-07-01 |website=icc |language=en}}</ref>


This victory marked India's first ICC title since the [[2013 ICC Champions Trophy]], their first world cup title since the [[2011 Cricket World Cup|2011 ICC Cricket World Cup]], and their second [[T20 World Cup]] crown with the first being the [[2007 ICC World Twenty20|2007]] title. Kohli's knock of 76 runs off 59 balls (including 6 fours and 2 sixes) earned him the [[Player of the Match]] award, while [[Jasprit Bumrah]] received the Player of the Tournament award for his outstanding bowling performance throughout the tournament. Bumrah ended up with 17 wickets towards the end of the tournament.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=29 June 2024 |title=India win T20 World Cup 2024, stun South Africa by 7 runs in final as Bumrah, Hardik nail finish |url=https://indianexpress.com/article/sports/cricket/india-win-t20-world-cup-2024-stun-south-africa-by-7-runs-in-final-9423182/ |website=The Indian Express}}</ref> [[Virat Kohli|Kohli]], [[Rohit Sharma|Sharma]] and [[Ravindra Jadeja|Jadeja]] announced their retirement from the [[Twenty20 International|T20 international]] format after the final.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=30 June 2024 |title=After Virat Kohli, Rohit Sharma announces T20I retirement following World Cup triumph |url=https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/cricket/story/rohit-sharma-t20i-retirement-virat-kohli-world-cup-triumph-barbados-2560206-2024-06-30 |website=India Today}}</ref> The end of the tournament also marked the end of [[Rahul Dravid|Rahul Dravid's]] tenure as the coach of the Indian cricket team as his contract was actually extended after the [[2023 Cricket World Cup]] until this T20 World Cup.
This victory marked India's first ICC title since the [[2013 ICC Champions Trophy]], their first world cup title since the [[2011 Cricket World Cup|2011 ICC Cricket World Cup]], and their second [[T20 World Cup]] crown with the first being the [[2007 ICC World Twenty20|2007]] title. Kohli's knock of 76 runs off 59 balls (including 6 fours and 2 sixes) earned him the [[Player of the Match]] award, while [[Jasprit Bumrah]] received the Player of the Tournament award for his outstanding bowling performance throughout the tournament. Bumrah ended up with 15 wickets towards the end of the tournament.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=29 June 2024 |title=India win T20 World Cup 2024, stun South Africa by 7 runs in final as Bumrah, Hardik nail finish |url=https://indianexpress.com/article/sports/cricket/india-win-t20-world-cup-2024-stun-south-africa-by-7-runs-in-final-9423182/ |website=The Indian Express}}</ref> [[Virat Kohli|Kohli]], [[Rohit Sharma|Sharma]] and [[Ravindra Jadeja|Jadeja]] announced their retirement from the [[Twenty20 International|T20 international]] format after the final.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=30 June 2024 |title=After Virat Kohli, Rohit Sharma announces T20I retirement following World Cup triumph |url=https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/cricket/story/rohit-sharma-t20i-retirement-virat-kohli-world-cup-triumph-barbados-2560206-2024-06-30 |website=India Today}}</ref> The end of the tournament also marked the end of [[Rahul Dravid|Rahul Dravid's]] tenure as the coach of the Indian cricket team as his contract was actually extended after the [[2023 Cricket World Cup]] until this T20 World Cup.

After they were both dismissed, [[Heinrich Klaasen]] made the fastest fifty in a World Cup final, including scoring 24 runs off the 15th over bowled by Axar Patel. Grenada

diff

2021-09-05T15:20:54Z
Line 235: Line 235:


===Military===
===Military===
Grenada has no standing military, leaving typical military functions to the [[Royal Grenada Police Force]] (including a Special Service Unit) and the [[Coast Guard of Grenada]].<ref name="CIA World Factbook - Grenada"/>
Since 1983, Grenada has no standing military, leaving typical military functions to the [[Royal Grenada Police Force]] (including a Special Service Unit) and the [[Coast Guard of Grenada]]. The [[People's Revolutionary Army (Grenada)|People's Revolutionary Army]] was the military of Grenada from 1979 to 1983. It was overthrown by the US Forces in the invasion in 1983.<ref name="CIA World Factbook - Grenada"/>


In 2019, Grenada signed the UN treaty on the [[Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons|Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=XXVI-9&chapter=26&clang=_en |title=Chapter XXVI: Disarmament&nbsp;‚Äì No. 9 Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons |publisher=United Nations Treaty Collection |date=7 July 2017}}</ref>
In 2019, Grenada signed the UN treaty on the [[Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons|Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=XXVI-9&chapter=26&clang=_en |title=Chapter XXVI: Disarmament&nbsp;‚Äì No. 9 Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons |publisher=United Nations Treaty Collection |date=7 July 2017}}</ref>

Woh Lamhe...

diff

2021-07-11T08:24:52Z
Line 23: Line 23:
}}
}}


'''''1Woh Lamhe...''''' ({{lang-en|Those Moments|italic=yes}}) is a 2006 Indian [[romantic drama]] film directed by [[Mohit Suri]], starring [[Shiney Ahuja]] and [[Kangana Ranaut]]. The film is supposedly based on [[Parveen Babi]]'s life, her battle with [[schizophrenia]] and her relationship with [[Mahesh Bhatt]] to whom she was a lover as well as a mentor in his struggling days.
'''''Woh Lamhe...''''' ({{lang-en|Those Moments|italic=yes}}) is a 2006 Indian [[romantic drama]] film directed by [[Mohit Suri]], starring [[Shiney Ahuja]] and [[Kangana Ranaut]]. The film is supposedly based on [[Parveen Babi]]'s life, her battle with [[schizophrenia]] and her relationship with [[Mahesh Bhatt]] to whom she was a lover as well as a mentor in his struggling days.


Bhatt said that it is his tribute to the actress and time he spent with her, hence the name ''Woh Lamhe...'' ("Those Moments"). [[Parveen Babi]]'s character is played by [[Kangana Ranaut]] who is named Sana Azim in the film to avoid direct reference to the actress. ''Woh Lamhe...'' was critically acclaimed for its screenplay, direction, and a noteworthy performance by Kangna. Ranaut‚Äôs performance in the film is considered to be one of her best.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.news18.com/amp/news/movies/7-films-that-made-kangana-ranaut-the-star-that-she-is-1363236.html|title=7 Films That Made Kangana Ranaut the Star That She Is|website=www.news18.com|access-date=2019-06-25}}</ref>
Bhatt said that it is his tribute to the actress and time he spent with her, hence the name ''Woh Lamhe...'' ("Those Moments"). [[Parveen Babi]]'s character is played by [[Kangana Ranaut]] who is named Sana Azim in the film to avoid direct reference to the actress. ''Woh Lamhe...'' was critically acclaimed for its screenplay, direction, and a noteworthy performance by Kangna. Ranaut‚Äôs performance in the film is considered to be one of her best.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.news18.com/amp/news/movies/7-films-that-made-kangana-ranaut-the-star-that-she-is-1363236.html|title=7 Films That Made Kangana Ranaut the Star That She Is|website=www.news18.com|access-date=2019-06-25}}</ref>

Woh Lamhe...

diff

2021-07-11T08:24:34Z
Line 30: Line 30:


== Plot ==
== Plot ==
In the glitzy entertainment capital of Mumbai as dusk descends, actress Sana Azim ([[Kangana Ranaut]]) slits her wrists in a hotel room in an attempt to kill herself. When this news reaches film-maker Aditya Garewal ([[Shiney Ahuja]]), he is devastated. Aditya has been searching for Sana, who was intensely involved with him and who had mysteriously disappeared from his life without any explanation three years ago, only to surface now in what could be the last moments of her life.
The film begins with a woman in a hotel room. She goes to the bathroom and slits her wrists in an attempt to kill herself. That woman is later revealed to be Sana Azim ([[Kangana Ranaut]]), a famous Bollywood actress. When this news reaches film-maker Aditya Garewal ([[Shiney Ahuja]]), he is devastated. Aditya has been searching for Sana, who was intensely involved with him and who had mysteriously disappeared from his life without any explanation three years ago, only to surface now in what could be the last moments of her life.


As Aditya waits outside of the ICU alongside Sam ([[Purab Kohli]]), praying to be reunited with her, he has a flashback of moments spent with her three years ago.
As Aditya waits outside of the ICU alongside Sam ([[Purab Kohli]]), praying to be reunited with her, he has a flashback of moments spent with her three years ago.


Sana had achieved stardom while Aditya was a struggling film director. He spots Sana at a fashion show where he rebukes her for being ugly indside-out. He insults her to a point where she throws her panty on him, thus garnering media attention. Nikhil ([[Shaad Randhawa]]), her abusive boyfriend, scolds her and rapes her. Sana's mother also scolds her for this act.
Sana had achieved stardom while Aditya was a struggling film director. He spots Sana at a fashion show where he rebukes her for being ugly indside-out. He insults her to a point where she throws her underwear on him, thus garnering media attention. Nikhil ([[Shaad Randhawa]]), her abusive boyfriend, scolds her and rapes her. Sana's mother also scolds her for this act.


Sana agrees at first to work with Aditya for his film but later she declines as she is bound by a contract. However, she breaks free from Nikhil's misery and agrees to work with Aditya.
Sana agrees at first to work with Aditya for his film but later she declines as she is bound by a contract. However, she breaks free from Nikhil's misery and agrees to work with Aditya.


Aditya starts shooting his film. During the shoot, both become close to each other. During the last day of the shoot, Sana tearfully says that she will miss him and those memories spent during the shoot. Aditya compares those memories to the sand castles on the beach by saying that those sand castles remain in our memories forever even though they are knocked down by the waves. During the film premiere, both fall in love with each other
Aditya starts shooting his film. During the shoot, both become close to each other. During the last day of the shoot, Sana tearfully says that she will miss him and those memories spent during the shoot. Aditya compares those memories to the sand castles on the beach by saying that those sand castles remain in our memories forever even though they are knocked down by the waves. During the film premiere, both fall in love with each other.


Everything goes well until a revelation is revealed. Sana is a patient with [[schizophrenia]], who has excessive hallucinations of a girl, Rani ([[Masumeh Makhija]]), who actually doesn't exist, which gradually ruins both Sana's life and career. When Aditya realizes that, the only way he can save Sana from total devastation, is to take her away from Bollywood and the vested interests, that threaten to destroy her completely he kidnaps her from the hospital thus putting his career on the line.
One day Sana spots a girl forcefully entering her hotel room. She tells Aditya that a girl named Rani ([[Masumeh Makhija]]) entered the room. However through the CCTV footage there was no girl who entered. It later revealed that Sana is a patient with [[schizophrenia]], who has excessive hallucinations of Rani who doesn't even exist, which gradually ruins both Sana's life and career. When Aditya realizes that, the only way he can save Sana from total devastation, is to take her away from Bollywood and the vested interests, that threaten to destroy her completely he kidnaps her from the hospital thus putting his career on the line.


Aditya tries his best to bring Sana back on track but in vain. She stops taking her medicines. During her birthday party, she faces her hallucinations once again and stabs Aditya.
Aditya tries his best to bring Sana back on track but in vain. She stops taking her medicines. During her birthday party, she faces her hallucinations once again and stabs Aditya.

Raaz 3: The Third Dimension

diff

2021-07-11T06:35:13Z
Line 25: Line 25:


==Plot==
==Plot==
The story revolves around Shanaya ([[Bipasha Basu]]), an ambitious actress. In addition, she also has a passionate affair with a director named Aditya ([[Emraan Hashmi]]). Her career takes a drastic roll when a newcomer, Sanjana ([[Esha Gupta]]) enters the film industry and comes into spotlight, receiving accolades and appreciation for her work. Suddenly, Shanaya seems forgotten and everybody only wants to work with Sanjana. Soon enough, Shanaya sees her career fading away and her envy slowly becomes craziness. She turns to black magic and makes it her goal in life to destroy Sanjana's career and make her feel the pain of loss.
Shanaya ([[Bipasha Basu]]) is an ambitious actress who has a passionate affair with a director named Aditya ([[Emraan Hashmi]]). Her career takes a drastic roll when a newcomer, Sanjana ([[Esha Gupta]]) enters the film industry and comes into spotlight, receiving accolades and appreciation for her work. Suddenly, Shanaya seems forgotten and everybody only wants to work with Sanjana. Soon enough, Shanaya sees her career fading away and her envy slowly becomes craziness. She turns to black magic and makes it her goal in life to destroy Sanjana's career and make her feel the pain of loss.


She seeks help of her former servant, Sonu (Sunil Dhariwal), a tantrik who helps her practice black magic and call upon an evil entity, Tara Dutt ([[Manish Choudhary]]). She asks him to destroy Sanjana's life and career. Tara agrees to help haunt and torture Sanjana until she becomes suicidal. He asks Shanaya to give Sanjana a black poison through a person she trusts. Shanaya [[has sex]] with Aditya to do it for her. Although reluctant at first, Aditya agrees due to his love for Shanaya but soon he realizes that what he's doing is immoral.
She seeks help of her former servant, Sonu (Sunil Dhariwal), a tantrik who helps her practice black magic and call upon an evil entity, Tara Dutt ([[Manish Choudhary]]). She asks him to destroy Sanjana's life and career. Tara agrees to help haunt and torture Sanjana until she becomes suicidal. He asks Shanaya to give Sanjana a black poison through a person she trusts. Shanaya seduces Aditya to do it for her. Although reluctant at first, Aditya agrees due to his love for Shanaya but soon he realizes that what he's doing is immoral.


Aditya, whose sympathy for Sanjana has now turned into love, leaves Shanaya and refuses to listen to her any more. To end Aditya's and Sanjana's love triangle, Shanaya hatches a plan by befriending Sanjana in order to poison her which Aditya gets suspicious about. At a movie premiere, Shanaya reveals that she actually hid the poison in the chocolate basket she gave to Sanjana earlier. In the bathroom, Sanjana is attacked by a swarm of moths that cause her to strip naked and run back to the party, thus getting exposed by the paparazzi and the people there. The public wrongly believe this to be a deliberate [[publicity stunt]] of hers, causing her career to be the verge of being ruined. Aditya takes her to a hospital and finds out that Shanaya was behind it. In rage, Aditya visits Shanaya's house and damages her possessions, taking away the last bit of the poisonous water.
Aditya, whose sympathy for Sanjana has now turned into love, leaves Shanaya and refuses to listen to her any more. To end Aditya's and Sanjana's love triangle, Shanaya hatches a plan by befriending Sanjana in order to poison her which Aditya gets suspicious about. At a movie premiere, Shanaya reveals that she actually hid the poison in the chocolate basket she gave to Sanjana earlier. In the bathroom, Sanjana is attacked by a swarm of moths that cause her to strip naked and run back to the party, thus getting exposed by the paparazzi and the people there. The public wrongly believe this to be a deliberate [[publicity stunt]] of hers, causing her career to be the verge of being ruined. Aditya takes her to a hospital and finds out that Shanaya was behind it. In rage, Aditya visits Shanaya's house and damages her possessions, taking away the last bit of the poisonous water.


Agitated, Shanaya seeks Tara Dutt's help again, wanting to kill Sanjana once and for all. Tara Dutt tells Shanaya that life and death are in God's hands and that to fight God he'll need her life force. He tells Shanaya that she has to conduct [[vaginal intercourse]] with him to enable Tara become powerful enough to fight God, to which Shanaya agrees. At the hospital, with the help of the doctor and a priest, Aditya goes into the spirit world to fight Tara Dutt. A hard fight ensues and Aditya defeats Tara Dutt, rescuing Sanjana's soul in the process. Back in the real world, Shanaya suffers physical damage as a result of the fight between Tara Dutt and Aditya and attempts to kill Aditya and Sanjana, only to meet failure. Aditya protects Sanjana from the defeated Shanaya, who vows that she will forever remain a star and commits suicide by pouring acid on her head, causing her skin to melt to death. Later, the media puts Sanjana off the hook as they conclude her 'publicity stunt' was a result of a [[nervous breakdown]] she had due to stress. The film ends with the moral that our love for others matters more than our love for ourselves.
Agitated, Shanaya seeks Tara Dutt's help again, wanting to kill Sanjana once and for all. Tara Dutt tells Shanaya that life and death are in God's hands and that to fight God he'll need her life force. He tells Shanaya that she has to has sex with him to enable Tara become powerful enough to fight God, to which Shanaya agrees. At the hospital, with the help of the doctor and a priest, Aditya goes into the spirit world to fight Tara Dutt. A hard fight ensues and Aditya defeats Tara Dutt, rescuing Sanjana's soul in the process. Back in the real world, Shanaya suffers physical damage as a result of the fight between Tara Dutt and Aditya and attempts to kill Aditya and Sanjana, only to meet failure. Aditya protects Sanjana from the defeated Shanaya, who vows that she will forever remain a star and commits suicide by pouring acid on her head, causing her skin to melt to death. Later, the media puts Sanjana off the hook as they conclude her 'publicity stunt' was a result of a [[nervous breakdown]] she had due to stress.
The film ends with the moral that our love for others matters more than our love for ourselves.

Tum Mile

diff

2021-07-05T15:20:41Z
Line 21: Line 21:
| gross = {{INR}}224 million
| gross = {{INR}}224 million
}}
}}
'''''Tum Mile''''' is a 2009 Indian [[Hindi]]-language [[Romance film|romantic]] [[disaster film]] directed by [[Kunal Deshmukh]], with story concept by Vishesh Bhatt. The film stars [[Emraan Hashmi]] and [[Soha Ali Khan]] in lead roles. It is a love story set against the backdrop of the infamous [[Maharashtra floods of 2005|July 2005 Mumbai floods]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.imdb.com/news/ni1196213/|title=Prime Focus recreates 26/7 Mumbai floods in Tum Mile |date=16 November 2009 |work=[[IMDb]] |publisher= |accessdate=17 December 2009}}</ref> The film was released on 13 November 2009.
'''''Tum Mile''''' (transl. I met you) is a 2009 Indian [[Hindi]]-language [[Romance film|romantic]] [[disaster film]] directed by [[Kunal Deshmukh]], with story concept by Vishesh Bhatt. The film stars [[Emraan Hashmi]] and [[Soha Ali Khan]] in lead roles. It is a love story set against the backdrop of the infamous [[Maharashtra floods of 2005|July 2005 Mumbai floods]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.imdb.com/news/ni1196213/|title=Prime Focus recreates 26/7 Mumbai floods in Tum Mile |date=16 November 2009 |work=[[IMDb]] |publisher= |accessdate=17 December 2009}}</ref> The film was released on 13 November 2009.

'''''Tum Mile''''' is a 2009 Indian [[Hindi]]-language [[Romance film|romantic]] [[disaster film]] directed by [[Kunal Deshmukh]], with story concept by Vishesh Bhatt. The film stars [[Emraan Hashmi]] and [[Soha Ali Khan]] in lead roles. It is a love story set against the backdrop of the infamous [[Maharashtra floods of 2005|July 2005 Mumbai floods]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.imdb.com/news/ni1196213/|title=Prime Focus recreates 26/7 Mumbai floods in Tum Mile |date=16 November 2009 |work=[[IMDb]] |publisher= |accessdate=17 December 2009}}</ref> The film was released on 13 November 2009.
'''''Tum Mile''''' (transl. You met) is a 2009 Indian [[Hindi]]-language [[Romance film|romantic]] [[disaster film]] directed by [[Kunal Deshmukh]], with story concept by Vishesh Bhatt. The film stars [[Emraan Hashmi]] and [[Soha Ali Khan]] in lead roles. It is a love story set against the backdrop of the infamous [[Maharashtra floods of 2005|July 2005 Mumbai floods]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.imdb.com/news/ni1196213/|title=Prime Focus recreates 26/7 Mumbai floods in Tum Mile |date=16 November 2009 |work=[[IMDb]] |publisher= |accessdate=17 December 2009}}</ref> The film was released on 13 November 2009.


== Plot ==
== Plot ==

Aksar

diff

2021-07-05T11:41:06Z
Line 114: Line 114:
The song will be recreated in the 2020 movie ''[[Chehre]]'' with Emraan Hashmi back to dance the song and Reshammiya to sing it again in a tropical [[Electronic dance music|EDM]] beat.
The song will be recreated in the 2020 movie ''[[Chehre]]'' with Emraan Hashmi back to dance the song and Reshammiya to sing it again in a tropical [[Electronic dance music|EDM]] beat.


The song was banned in a village called [[Bhalej]] in [[Anand district]] of [[Gujarat]] by locals who claimed that the song "attracted ghosts". Apparently, people who sang the song said they were possessed by spirits and started behaving in a strange way. They reasoned that one of the lines " ek baar aaja aaja aaja aaja aaaja" (literally "come come come come come just for once") invited ghosts. Also this led to a rumour that if this song was played late at night, especially the above line, it would attract the ghosts. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/himeshs-song-invites-ghosts-in-guj/11986-8-0.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130709095322/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/himeshs-song-invites-ghosts-in-guj/11986-8-0.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2013-07-09 |title=Himesh's song invites ghosts in Guj |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movies/news/type/view/id/1191542/sorttype/Bollywood%20films%20to%20get%20special%20focus%20at%20London%20Film%20Festival |title=Himeshs Jhalak Dikhlaja track inviting ghosts literally &#124; Bollywood News &#124; Hindi Movies News &#124; Celebrity News |publisher=BollywoodHungama.com |date=2006-06-01 |accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/archive-news/|title=Hindustan Times - Archive News|website=hindustantimes}}</ref>
The song was banned in a village called [[Bhalej]] in [[Anand district]] of [[Gujarat]] by locals who claimed that the song summoned ghosts. Apparently, people who sang the song said they were possessed by spirits and started behaving in a strange way. They reasoned that one of the lines " ek baar aaja aaja aaja aaja aaaja" (literally "come come come come come just for once") invited ghosts. Also this led to a rumour that if this song was played late at night, especially the above line, it would summon the ghosts. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/himeshs-song-invites-ghosts-in-guj/11986-8-0.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130709095322/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/himeshs-song-invites-ghosts-in-guj/11986-8-0.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2013-07-09 |title=Himesh's song invites ghosts in Guj |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movies/news/type/view/id/1191542/sorttype/Bollywood%20films%20to%20get%20special%20focus%20at%20London%20Film%20Festival |title=Himeshs Jhalak Dikhlaja track inviting ghosts literally &#124; Bollywood News &#124; Hindi Movies News &#124; Celebrity News |publisher=BollywoodHungama.com |date=2006-06-01 |accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/archive-news/|title=Hindustan Times - Archive News|website=hindustantimes}}</ref>

Aksar

diff

2021-07-05T11:39:32Z
Line 114: Line 114:
The song will be recreated in the 2020 movie ''[[Chehre]]'' with Emraan Hashmi back to dance the song and Reshammiya to sing it again in a tropical [[Electronic dance music|EDM]] beat.
The song will be recreated in the 2020 movie ''[[Chehre]]'' with Emraan Hashmi back to dance the song and Reshammiya to sing it again in a tropical [[Electronic dance music|EDM]] beat.


The song was banned in a village called [[Bhalej]] in [[Anand district]] of [[Gujarat]] by locals who claimed that the song "attracted ghosts". Apparently, people who sang the song said they were possessed by spirits and started behaving in a strange way. They reasoned that the lyrics "aaja aaja" (literally "come come") invited ghosts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/himeshs-song-invites-ghosts-in-guj/11986-8-0.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130709095322/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/himeshs-song-invites-ghosts-in-guj/11986-8-0.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2013-07-09 |title=Himesh's song invites ghosts in Guj |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movies/news/type/view/id/1191542/sorttype/Bollywood%20films%20to%20get%20special%20focus%20at%20London%20Film%20Festival |title=Himeshs Jhalak Dikhlaja track inviting ghosts literally &#124; Bollywood News &#124; Hindi Movies News &#124; Celebrity News |publisher=BollywoodHungama.com |date=2006-06-01 |accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/archive-news/|title=Hindustan Times - Archive News|website=hindustantimes}}</ref>
The song was banned in a village called [[Bhalej]] in [[Anand district]] of [[Gujarat]] by locals who claimed that the song "attracted ghosts". Apparently, people who sang the song said they were possessed by spirits and started behaving in a strange way. They reasoned that one of the lines " ek baar aaja aaja aaja aaja aaaja" (literally "come come come come come just for once") invited ghosts. Also this led to a rumour that if this song was played late at night, especially the above line, it would attract the ghosts. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/himeshs-song-invites-ghosts-in-guj/11986-8-0.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130709095322/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/himeshs-song-invites-ghosts-in-guj/11986-8-0.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=2013-07-09 |title=Himesh's song invites ghosts in Guj |publisher=Ibnlive.in.com |date= |accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/movies/news/type/view/id/1191542/sorttype/Bollywood%20films%20to%20get%20special%20focus%20at%20London%20Film%20Festival |title=Himeshs Jhalak Dikhlaja track inviting ghosts literally &#124; Bollywood News &#124; Hindi Movies News &#124; Celebrity News |publisher=BollywoodHungama.com |date=2006-06-01 |accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/archive-news/|title=Hindustan Times - Archive News|website=hindustantimes}}</ref>

Marathi people

diff

2021-06-20T16:29:46Z
Line 372: Line 372:
In the mid-1950s, the 'little magazine movement' gained momentum. It published writings which were non-conformist, radical, and experimental. The [[Dalit literature]] movement also gained strength due to the little magazine movement. This radical movement was influenced by the philosophy of non-conformity, and challenged the literary establishment, which was largely middle class, urban, and upper [[caste]].<ref name=han>[https://books.google.com/books?id=1lTnv6o-d_oC&pg=PA368&dq=Baburao+Bagul&lr= Issues of Language and Representation:Babu Rao Bagul] ''Handbook of twentieth-century literatures of India'', Editors: Nalini Natarajan, Emmanuel Sampath Nelson. Greenwood Publishing Group, 1996. {{ISBN|0-313-28778-3}}. '' Page 368''.</ref> The little magazine movement was responsible for many excellent writers including the well-known novelist, critic, and poet [[Bhalchandra Nemade]]. Dalit writer [[N. D. Mahanor]] is well known for his work, while Dr. Sharad Rane is a well-known children's writer.<ref>{{cite book|last=Nagarkar|first=Kiran|title=The Language Conflicts: The Politics and Hostilities between English and the Regional Languages in India|year=2006|url=http://www.khg.uni.wroc.pl/files/khg7nagarkart.pdf}}</ref>
In the mid-1950s, the 'little magazine movement' gained momentum. It published writings which were non-conformist, radical, and experimental. The [[Dalit literature]] movement also gained strength due to the little magazine movement. This radical movement was influenced by the philosophy of non-conformity, and challenged the literary establishment, which was largely middle class, urban, and upper [[caste]].<ref name=han>[https://books.google.com/books?id=1lTnv6o-d_oC&pg=PA368&dq=Baburao+Bagul&lr= Issues of Language and Representation:Babu Rao Bagul] ''Handbook of twentieth-century literatures of India'', Editors: Nalini Natarajan, Emmanuel Sampath Nelson. Greenwood Publishing Group, 1996. {{ISBN|0-313-28778-3}}. '' Page 368''.</ref> The little magazine movement was responsible for many excellent writers including the well-known novelist, critic, and poet [[Bhalchandra Nemade]]. Dalit writer [[N. D. Mahanor]] is well known for his work, while Dr. Sharad Rane is a well-known children's writer.<ref>{{cite book|last=Nagarkar|first=Kiran|title=The Language Conflicts: The Politics and Hostilities between English and the Regional Languages in India|year=2006|url=http://www.khg.uni.wroc.pl/files/khg7nagarkart.pdf}}</ref>


== Martial tradition ==
== Military tradition ==
Although ethnic Marathis have taken up military roles for many centuries,<ref name="Minahan2012">{{cite book|author=James B. Minahan|title=Ethnic Groups of South Asia and the Pacific: An Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fOQkpcVcd9AC&pg=PA178|date=30 August 2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-660-7|page=178 |access-date=9 May 2013}}</ref> their martial qualities came to prominence in seventeenth century India, under the leadership of Shivaji. He founded the Maratha Empire, which at the time of the mid [[18th century]] controlled practically the entire Indian subcontinent.<ref>{{cite book|title=Career's Indian History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_p5B-PUf-_sC&q=maratha+empire+whole+of+india&pg=PA141|publisher=Bright Publications|page=141}}</ref><ref name="KhanHussain1999">{{cite book|author1=Ansar Hussain Khan|author2=Ansar Hussain|title=Rediscovery of India, The: A New Subcontinent|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XRpFol4AnO0C&pg=PA133|date=1 January 1999|publisher=Orient Blackswan|isbn=978-81-250-1595-6|page=133}}</ref> It was largely an ethnic Marathi polity,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fOQkpcVcd9AC&q=maratha+empire+marathi+ethnic&pg=PT234|title=Ethnic Groups of South Asia and the Pacific: An Encyclopedia|isbn=9781598846607|last1=Minahan|first1=James B.|date=30 August 2012}}</ref> with its chiefs and nobles coming from the Marathi ethnicity, such as the [[Bhonsle|Chhatrapatis]] (''Maratha'' caste), the [[Maharaja Holkar]]s (''Dhangar'' caste),<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5kMrsTj1NeYC&q=holkar+dhangar+caste&pg=PA21|title=Caste, Conflict and Ideology|isbn=9780521523080|last1=O'Hanlon|first1=Rosalind|date=22 August 2002}}</ref> the [[Peshwa]]s (1713 onwards) (''Chitpavan'' caste),<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|url=http://www.britannica.com/topic/Citpavan|title=Citpavan - Indian caste|encyclopedia=Encyclop√¶dia Britannica}}</ref> the Angres, chief of [[Maratha Navy]] (''Koli'' caste)(1698 onwards).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bakshi|first1=SR|title=Contemporary Political Leadership in India|publisher=APH Publishing Corporation|page=41|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iP433CnEW_gC&q=koli+angre&pg=PA41|isbn=9788176480079|year=1998}}</ref> The Maratha Empire is credited to a large extent for ending the Mughal rule in India.<ref>
Although ethnic Marathis have taken up military roles for many centuries,<ref name="Minahan2012">{{cite book|author=James B. Minahan|title=Ethnic Groups of South Asia and the Pacific: An Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fOQkpcVcd9AC&pg=PA178|date=30 August 2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-660-7|page=178 |access-date=9 May 2013}}</ref> their martial qualities came to prominence in seventeenth century India, under the leadership of Shivaji. He founded the Maratha Empire, which at the time of the mid [[18th century]] controlled practically the entire Indian subcontinent.<ref>{{cite book|title=Career's Indian History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_p5B-PUf-_sC&q=maratha+empire+whole+of+india&pg=PA141|publisher=Bright Publications|page=141}}</ref><ref name="KhanHussain1999">{{cite book|author1=Ansar Hussain Khan|author2=Ansar Hussain|title=Rediscovery of India, The: A New Subcontinent|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XRpFol4AnO0C&pg=PA133|date=1 January 1999|publisher=Orient Blackswan|isbn=978-81-250-1595-6|page=133}}</ref> It was largely an ethnic Marathi polity,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fOQkpcVcd9AC&q=maratha+empire+marathi+ethnic&pg=PT234|title=Ethnic Groups of South Asia and the Pacific: An Encyclopedia|isbn=9781598846607|last1=Minahan|first1=James B.|date=30 August 2012}}</ref> with its chiefs and nobles coming from the Marathi ethnicity, such as the [[Bhonsle|Chhatrapatis]] (''Maratha'' caste), the [[Maharaja Holkar]]s (''Dhangar'' caste),<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5kMrsTj1NeYC&q=holkar+dhangar+caste&pg=PA21|title=Caste, Conflict and Ideology|isbn=9780521523080|last1=O'Hanlon|first1=Rosalind|date=22 August 2002}}</ref> the [[Peshwa]]s (1713 onwards) (''Chitpavan'' caste),<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|url=http://www.britannica.com/topic/Citpavan|title=Citpavan - Indian caste|encyclopedia=Encyclop√¶dia Britannica}}</ref> the Angres, chief of [[Maratha Navy]] (''Koli'' caste)(1698 onwards).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bakshi|first1=SR|title=Contemporary Political Leadership in India|publisher=APH Publishing Corporation|page=41|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iP433CnEW_gC&q=koli+angre&pg=PA41|isbn=9788176480079|year=1998}}</ref> The Maratha Empire is credited to a large extent for ending the Mughal rule in India.<ref>

As Aditya waits outside of the ICU alongside Sam ([[Purab Kohli]]), praying to be reunited with her, he has a flashback of moments spent with her three years ago.
As Aditya waits outside of the ICU alongside Sam ([[Purab Kohli]]), praying to be reunited with her, he has a flashback of moments spent with her three years ago.


Sana had achieved stardom while Aditya was a struggling film director. He spots Sana at a fashion show where he rebukes her for being ugly indside-out. He insults her at a point where she throws her panty on him, thus garnering media attention. Nikhil ([[Shaad Randhawa]]), her abusive boyfriend, scolds her and rapes her. Sana's mother also scolds her for this act.

He insults her to a point where she throws her panty on him, thus garnering media attention. Nikhil ([[Shaad Randhawa]]), her abusive boyfriend, scolds her and rapes her. Sana's mother also scolds her for this act.

Bachna Ae Haseeno

diff

2021-06-17T17:51:33Z
Line 48: Line 48:
On his return to India, in [[Amritsar]], in 2008, he first seeks out Mahi, who is now married and has two sons. Her husband Joginder ([[Kunal Kapoor (actor, born 1977)|Kunal Kapoor]]) recognises Raj and knocks him out. He blames Raj for Mahi no longer believing in love or romance because of him, although he explains that she is a perfect housewife and has a perfect home. At Joginder's brother's ''sangeet'' ceremony Raj apologises to Mahi and convinces her that her husband is her true love. She opens up to Joginder and forgives Raj.
On his return to India, in [[Amritsar]], in 2008, he first seeks out Mahi, who is now married and has two sons. Her husband Joginder ([[Kunal Kapoor (actor, born 1977)|Kunal Kapoor]]) recognises Raj and knocks him out. He blames Raj for Mahi no longer believing in love or romance because of him, although he explains that she is a perfect housewife and has a perfect home. At Joginder's brother's ''sangeet'' ceremony Raj apologises to Mahi and convinces her that her husband is her true love. She opens up to Joginder and forgives Raj.


Raj then searches for Radhika and discovers that she has changed her name to Shreya and has become a successful supermodel. Raj tries to meet Shreya at an event but she ignores him. He follows her to [[Italy]] where she goes for a vacation. Raj finally meets Shreya but she refuses to accept his apologies and tells him that if he really wants her forgiveness, he will have to work for it. To do this, Raj becomes her personal assistant and she makes him do all sorts of tasks, even serving at parties. She humiliates him on every occasion, but he remains firm, serving without complaint. She finally gives up and tells him how hurt she had felt back then, and asks him to leave. However, before Raj goes home, she arrives and tells him that she realised that the root of her frustration was bottled-up hate against him that she no longer bears.
Raj then searches for Radhika and discovers that she has changed her name to Shreya and has become a successful supermodel. Raj tries to meet Shreya at an event but she ignores him. He follows her to [[Capri]] in [[Italy]] where she goes for a vacation. Raj finally meets Shreya but she refuses to accept his apologies and tells him that if he really wants her forgiveness, he will have to work for it. To do this, Raj becomes her personal assistant and she makes him do all sorts of tasks, even serving at parties. She humiliates him on every occasion, but he remains firm, serving without complaint. She finally gives up and tells him how hurt she had felt back then, and asks him to leave. However, before Raj goes home, she arrives and tells him that she realised that the root of her frustration was bottled-up hate against him that she no longer bears.


Content, Raj returns to Australia. On his return, he finds a pile of letters from Gayatri, written over the six months he was gone. Raj meets Gayatri in her taxi. She regrets turning him down. The lovers reconcile and confess their love.
Content, Raj returns to Australia. On his return, he finds a pile of letters from Gayatri, written over the six months he was gone. Raj meets Gayatri in her taxi. She regrets turning him down. The lovers reconcile and confess their love.

Line 32: Line 32:
In the glitzy entertainment capital of Mumbai as dusk descends, actress Sana Azim ([[Kangana Ranaut]]) slits her wrists in a hotel room in an attempt to kill herself. When this news reaches film-maker Aditya Garewal ([[Shiney Ahuja]]), he is devastated. Aditya has been searching for Sana, who was intensely involved with him and who had mysteriously disappeared from his life without any explanation three years ago, only to surface now in what could be the last moments of her life.
In the glitzy entertainment capital of Mumbai as dusk descends, actress Sana Azim ([[Kangana Ranaut]]) slits her wrists in a hotel room in an attempt to kill herself. When this news reaches film-maker Aditya Garewal ([[Shiney Ahuja]]), he is devastated. Aditya has been searching for Sana, who was intensely involved with him and who had mysteriously disappeared from his life without any explanation three years ago, only to surface now in what could be the last moments of her life.


As Aditya waits outside of the ICU alongside Sam ([[Purab Kohli]]), praying to be reunited with her, he has a flashback of moments spent with her.
As Aditya waits outside of the ICU alongside Sam ([[Purab Kohli]]), praying to be reunited with her, he has a flashback of moments spent with her three years ago.


Three years before Aditya was a struggling film director. He spots Sana at a fashion show where he rebukes her for being ugly indside-out. He insults her at a point where she throws her panty on him, thus garnering media attention. Nikhil ([[Shaad Randhawa]]), her abusive boyfriend, scolds her and rapes her. Sana's mother also scolds her for this act.
Sana had achieved stardom while Aditya was a struggling film director. He spots Sana at a fashion show where he rebukes her for being ugly indside-out. He insults her at a point where she throws her panty on him, thus garnering media attention. Nikhil ([[Shaad Randhawa]]), her abusive boyfriend, scolds her and rapes her. Sana's mother also scolds her for this act.


Sana agrees at first to work with Aditya for his film but later she declines as she is bound by a contract. However, she breaks free from Nikhil's misery and agrees to work with Aditya.
Sana agrees at first to work with Aditya for his film but later she declines as she is bound by a contract. However, she breaks free from Nikhil's misery and agrees to work with Aditya.

Woh Lamhe...

diff

2021-06-17T17:43:34Z
Line 48: Line 48:
Aditya starts shooting his film. During the shoot, both become close to each other. During the last day of the shoot, Sana tearfully says that she will miss him and those memories spent during the shoot. Aditya compares those memories to the sand castles on the beach by saying that those sand castles remain in our memories forever even though they are knocked down by the waves. During the film premiere, both fall in love with each other
Aditya starts shooting his film. During the shoot, both become close to each other. During the last day of the shoot, Sana tearfully says that she will miss him and those memories spent during the shoot. Aditya compares those memories to the sand castles on the beach by saying that those sand castles remain in our memories forever even though they are knocked down by the waves. During the film premiere, both fall in love with each other


Everything goes well until a revelation is revealed. Sana is a patient with schizophrenia, who has excessive hallucinations of a girl named Rani, who actually doesn't exist, which gradually ruins both Sana's life and career. When Aditya realizes that, the only way he can save Sana from total devastation, is to take her away from Bollywood and the vested interests, that threaten to destroy her completely he kidnaps her from the hospital thus putting his career on the line.
Everything goes well until a revelation is revealed. Sana is a patient with schizophrenia, who has excessive hallucinations of a girl named Rani ([[Masumeh Makhija]]), who actually doesn't exist, which gradually ruins both Sana's life and career. When Aditya realizes that, the only way he can save Sana from total devastation, is to take her away from Bollywood and the vested interests, that threaten to destroy her completely he kidnaps her from the hospital thus putting his career on the line.


Aditya tries his best to bring Sana back on track but in vain. She stops taking her medicines. During her birthday party, she faces her hallucinations once again and stabs Aditya.
Aditya tries his best to bring Sana back on track but in vain. She stops taking her medicines. During her birthday party, she faces her hallucinations once again and stabs Aditya.

* [[Purab Kohli]] as Sam aka Sammy


== Synopsis ==
== Plot ==
In the glitzy entertainment capital of Mumbai as dusk descends, actress Sana Azim ([[Kangana Ranaut]]) slits her wrists in a hotel room in an attempt to kill herself. When this news reaches film-maker Aditya Garewal ([[Shiney Ahuja]]), he is devastated. Aditya has been searching for Sana, who was intensely involved with him and who had mysteriously disappeared from his life without any explanation three years ago, only to surface now in what could be the last moments of her life.
In the glitzy entertainment capital of Mumbai as dusk descends, actress Sana Azim ([[Kangana Ranaut]]) slits her wrists in a hotel room in an attempt to kill herself. When this news reaches film-maker Aditya Garewal ([[Shiney Ahuja]]), he is devastated. Aditya has been searching for Sana, who was intensely involved with him and who had mysteriously disappeared from his life without any explanation three years ago, only to surface now in what could be the last moments of her life.


As Aditya waits outside of the ICU, praying to be reunited with her, he is hurled back into the perfumed days and champagne nights of his memory, when Sana played the role of a lover and mentor to a struggling Aditya.
As Aditya waits outside of the ICU alongside Sam ([[Purab Kohli]]), praying to be reunited with her, he has a flashback of moments spent with her.


Three years before Aditya was a struggling film director. He spots Sana at a fashion show where he rebukes her for being ugly indside-out. He insults her at a point where she throws her panty on him, thus garnering media attention. Nikhil, her abusive boyfriend, scolds her and rapes her. Sana's mother also scolds her for this act.
Everything was perfect, except for an enemy which lurked in the shadows, waiting to destroy their love. Sana is a patient with schizophrenia, who has excessive hallucinations of a girl named Rani, who actually doesn't exist, which gradually ruins both Sana's life and career. When Aditya realizes that, the only way he can save Sana from total devastation, is to take her away from Bollywood and the vested interests, that threaten to destroy her completely, he runs away with Sana putting his career on the line. Those moments lived in the sanctuary of their love are like an oasis in the desert.


Sana agrees at first to work with Aditya for his film but later she declines as she is bound by a contract. However, she breaks free from Nikhil's misery and agrees to work with Aditya.
Until one day, suddenly, she disappears, leaving him with unanswered questions.


Aditya starts shooting his film. During the shoot, both become close to each other. During the last day of the shoot, Sana tearfully says that she will miss him and those memories spent during the shoot. Aditya compares those memories to the sand castles on the beach by saying that those sand castles remain in our memories forever even though they are knocked down by the waves. During the film premiere, both fall in love with each other
Aditya tries his best to save Sana from her mental illness but fails. Sana remains now only in his memories and past moments.

Everything goes well until a revelation is revealed. Sana is a patient with schizophrenia, who has excessive hallucinations of a girl named Rani, who actually doesn't exist, which gradually ruins both Sana's life and career. When Aditya realizes that, the only way he can save Sana from total devastation, is to take her away from Bollywood and the vested interests, that threaten to destroy her completely he kidnaps her from the hospital thus putting his career on the line.

Aditya tries his best to bring Sana back on track but in vain. She stops taking her medicines. During her birthday party, she faces her hallucinations once again and stabs Aditya.

Until one day, suddenly, she disappears, leaving him with unanswered questions. Aditya is shocked. Meanwhile, Nikhil and the police reach the place and takes Aditya. Nikhil asks him in anger about Sana's whereabouts to which Aditya repeatedly says that he doesn't know.

Back in the present, Aditya is told that Sana has very less time and wants to meet him. They both profess their love for each other and she dies. Nikhil asks him what he will do next to which Aditya replies that he doesn't know.

The film ends with Aditya reminiscing the thoughts about her on a beach. He spots some children making a sand castle and remembers his metaphor. He goes and makes castles with them.

==Critical reception==
